#infrastructure @RepGarretGraves noted that we spend a lot of money going through lengthy project review and planning processes. @MayorOfLA Garcetti encouraged Congress to do whatever it can to streamline bureaucracy & processes.
Responding to @RepGregPence, @GovTimWalz said that we need to reward states for innovation, and help the states that need it to do it better ‚Äì doing so will help the entire #infrastructure network.

Following up, @GovTimWalz said that we need to be good stewards of the taxpayers‚Äô money, but we can‚Äôt be so risk-averse to technology.  States need incentives to innovate and invest in projects that incorporate new technologies.
In response, @MayorOfLA Garcetti said that we need to be ‚Äúfuture-forward, not future-resistant,‚Äù and that we don‚Äôt want to pass 20th century legislation for 21st century #infrastructure.

Asking about technology, @RepRossSpano asked witnesses to address the need for balance between long-term #infrastructure project planning and ability to nimbly respond to new developments in technology.
To help states and local governments improve #infrastructure, @GovTimWalz responded to @RepBalderson that sometimes a carrot works much better than the stick.

Why we need to streamline #infrastructure project delivery: LA Mayor Garcetti @MayorOfLA, responding to @RodneyDavis, testified that what we call environmental law is now really something for NIMBYs to use to stop or slow down projects.
#infrastructure cybersecurity - @RepGallagher made point that as we continue moving to smart technologies, we need to make sure we are not giving our enemies a back door to our systems.

@RepWesterman noted the importance of US waterways, and the bang for the buck we get when investing in this #infrastructure. @GovTimWalz said we are an accident away from not moving commerce out of this country.

Mayor Garcetti @MayorOfLA talked about technology to electrify the LA (and US) bus fleet, but noted "because this is America, we may move a little slower‚Äù in incorporating the tech. T&I GOP want to ensure safe & efficient use of new techs to help solve #infrastructure issues
In exchange between @RepBrianBabin and LA Mayor Garcetti, @MayorOfLA said streamlining #infrastructure project delivery process would be ‚Äúmusic to our ears,‚Äù particularly after disasters.
More @RepMarkMeadows: asked witnesses to recommend an ultimate solution to our long-term #infrastructure funding question, so we don‚Äôt have to keep coming back to the same issue.

At our #infrastructure hearing @RepMarkMeadows talked about the need to streamline the project delivery process. MN Governor @GovTimWalz agreed with his frustrations, saying governors don‚Äôt want to cut corners, but projects shouldn‚Äôt take so long.

LA Mayor Garcetti @MayorOfLA, responding to ? from @RepWebster, talked about using new technologies that will ensure our #infrastructure lasts longer.  @GovTimWalz added that states want flexibility to use technologies that best suit their own areas.
Governor @GovTimWalz to @RepBobGibbs: On #infrastructure, give states flexibility and room to innovate
#infrastructure - @RepBobGibbs the gas tax is on the decline ‚Äì vehicles getting more fuel efficient and more aren‚Äôt paying their share into Highway Trust Fund

T&I Ranking Member Sam Graves: I agree with Chairman DeFazio that we can‚Äôt afford to do nothing.  But we also can‚Äôt afford to miss this opportunity to unleash innovation in a way that can slingshot our #infrastructure, and our economy, into the future.

In 2018, Republicans oversaw passage of bipartisan FEMA reforms that will help communities resist and recover from disaster. #DRRA

Republicans led the way in the House on our current bipartisan surface transportation law ‚Äì FAST Act.  The first long-term bill of its kind in 10 yrs, it‚Äôs sending hundreds of $ billions to all 50 states to fix roads & bridges. Let‚Äôs keep going.
Led by Republicans last year, Congress sent 5-year bipartisan FAA & aviation infrastructure bill (the longest since 1982) to @POTUS for his signature.

Republicans have a proven track record on infrastructure. We led the way in ensuring hundreds of billions of dollars in investment in recent years but agree our work isn‚Äôt done.  We‚Äôre ready to keep working together on this issue for the American people.
The @POTUS was clear in #SOTU last night that he is eager for a bipartisan #infrastructure effort in Congress.
Committee Republicans are ready to work w/ the Administration to incorporate goals such as ensuring that technology plays a key role in the future of our infrastructure. #SOTU
But there is more to do, and we are ready to continue working with our colleagues to improve America‚Äôs infrastructure.

In recent Congresses, under Republican leadership, our committee saw many important bipartisan #infrastructure bills enacted into law:
‚úî 5-year FAA reauthorization 
‚úî 5-year surface transportation reauthorization ‚Äì FAST Act
‚úî3 WRDA bills
‚úîFEMA disaster program reforms

Now is a golden opportunity to work together on a bipartisan bill that can get broad support, that fixes and improves crumbling infrastructure, and addresses our long-term transportation funding issue.

Looking ahead, many ideas to improve our infrastructure will be on the table.  We need to think about how we can address our infrastructure issues for the long-term and deliver the infrastructure system Americans deserve for our future.

But we have more work to do in the coming months ‚Äì as part of an infrastructure package & other important must-pass legislation.  We look forward to working with @WhiteHouse, @HouseDemocrats, @HouseGOP, & the Senate to deliver America more wins.
We‚Äôve also passed laws to support our Coast Guard and maritime transportation system, improve pipeline safety, and make communities better prepared to withstand disasters.
Additionally, we signed into law legislation to invest in our airports and aviation system. With these several laws alone, we‚Äôve invested over $380 billion in our infrastructure.

When it comes to #infrastructure, Congress has a good track record.  In recent years, we passed a major long-term transportation bill to improve roads, bridges, rails, & public transit; multiple bills to enhance US ports & inland waterways.
